document.masterDocTitle: Kalanura-a new genus of Neanurini (Collembola, Neanuridae, Neanurinae) from Siberia, with description of four new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Kalanura-a new genus of Neanurini (Collembola, Neanuridae, Neanurinae) from Siberia, with description of four new species

95

under

Kalanura stebaevae
sp. nov.
: 19, ventral chaetotaxy of abd. II–VI; 20, dorsal chaetotaxy of abd. V– VI; 21, tubercle L of abd. IV.

Peltigera ephthosa
,
12.VIII.1977
, leg. S. Stebaeva. Juvenile

Cladonia sp.
, 12.VIII.1977 , leg. S. Stebaeva. Male, same place, mixed fir–larch forest, on larch stump under
Evernia mesomorpha
, 12.VIII.1977 , leg. S. Stebaeva. Adult
female, Russia , Republic of Tuva , southern slope of East Tannu–Ola Mt. Range , vicinity of Khol’–Oozhu settl. (50
0 44’ N
94
0 23’ E
), alpine tundra,
2175 m a.s.l.
,
17.VI.1995
, leg. S. Stebaeva. Adult
male and juvenile, Russia , Republic of Tuva , southern slope of East Tannu–Ola Mt. Range , vicinity of Khol’–Oozhu settl., way to Kara–Khol’ lake (50
0 38’ N
95
0 19’ E
), mixed pine–larch forest,
16.VII.1993
, leg. S. Stebaeva.

Diagnosis. Buccal cone short. Labral chaetotaxy 4/2, 4. Mandible thin with 4 teeth. Head with 3 chaetae Oc, chaetae A, B, C, D, E and O. Tubercles Dl, L and So with 6, 4 and 6 chaetae respectively. Tubercles Di and De on thoracic tergum I separate. Tubercles De on thoracic terga II and III with 4 and 5 chaetae respectively. Tubercles L on abdominal terga III and IV with 4 and 6–7 chaetae respectively. Tubercles Di on thoracic tergum V separate. Cryptopygy present.
Etymology. The name is derived from the Latin word “specto”–magnificent, admirable, noteworthy.

Description. Body length (without antennae): 0.95–1.85 mm ( holotype : 1.45 mm). Habitus typical of the
Neanurini
( Cassagnau 1989 ). Colour of the body greyish–blue. 3+3 relatively large, dark–pigmented eyes ( Fig. 29 ).

Types of dorsal ordinary chaetae: macrochaetae Ml thickened, narrowly sheathed, distinctly serrated and apically rounded (as on Fig. 10 ); Mc and Mcc thickened, pointed or rounded at apex; mesochaetae thin and pointed.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 22–28 .
Kalanura spectabilis
sp. nov.
: 22, habitus and dorsal chaetotaxy (holotype); 23, chaetotaxy of labrum; 24, chaetotaxy of labium; 25, mandible; 26, maxilla; 27, ventral chaetotaxy of abd. V–VI; 28, tubercle L of abd. V.

TABLE 4 . Chaetotaxy of
Kalanura spectabilis
sp. nov.
.

tr.td: Number of other cephalic chaetae: Vi, 6; Ve, 10; labrum, 4/2,4; labium, 10, 0x; ant. I, 7; ant.II, 12; ant. III, 18+5s; ant. IV,

subSubSection.paragraph: Head. Buccal cone short. Labrum pointed, with ventral sclerifications ogival as in Fig. 23 . Labrum chaetotaxy 4/2, 4 ( Fig. 23 ). Chaetotaxy of labium as in Fig. 24 . Maxilla styliform ( Fig. 26 ), mandible thin, with two small apical and two basal teeth ( Fig. 25 ). Chaetotaxy of antennae as in Tab. 4 . Apical bulb distinct, trilobed. S-chaetae subequal, long and moderately thickened. Chaetotaxy of head as in Figs 22 , 29 and in Tab. 4 . Tubercles Dl, L and So separated ( Fig. 29 ). Tubercles Di and De not fused. Chaetae D absent, chaeta O present ( Fig. 29 ). Chaeta A slightly shorter than B.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 29–31.
Kalanura spectabilis
sp. nov.
: 29, dorsal and lateral chaetotaxy of head; 30, ventral chaetotaxy of abd. III–V; 31, dorsal chaetotaxy of abd. V–VI.

subSubSection.paragraph: Thorax, abdomen, legs. Chetotaxy of th. and abd. as in Figs 22, 27–28 , 30–31 and in Tab. 4 . Tubercles Di and De on th. I not fused ( Fig. 22 ). Tubercles De on th. II and III with 4 and 5 chaetae respectively ( Fig. 22 ). Tubercle L on abd. IV with 6 chaetae ( Fig. 30 ). S-chaetae distinctly shorter than nearby macrochaetae ( Figs 22 , 31 ). Abd.V with four tubercles: 2(Di+De+Dl) and 2L ( Figs 22 , 31 ). Tubercle L on abd.V with 4–5 chaetae ( Figs 27-28 ). Weak cryptopygy ( Figs 22 , 31 ). Chaetotaxy of legs as in Tab. 4 . Claw untoothed.

Discussion. The new species is similar to
Kalanura compacta
sp. nov.
(described above), and differences between them are given in the key.
